user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 is: A function parameter should not be modified.
Note that the object referred to by a pointer parameter may be modified, but the pointer itself shall not be modified.
</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_CondVarSignal:
```c
int32 OS_CondVarSignal(osal_id_t var_id)
{
    OS_object_token_t token;
    int32             return_code;

    /* Check Parameters */
    return_code = OS_ObjectIdGetById(OS_LOCK_MODE_NONE, OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_CONDVAR, var_id, &token);
    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        return_code = OS_CondVarSignal_Impl(&token);
    }

    return return_code;
}
```
</target_code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
return_code = OS_CondVarSignal_Impl(&token);
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 17.8 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: No violation in the shown fragment: passing &token to OS_CondVarSignal_Impl does not itself modify a function parameter. A specific violation scenario would be if OS_CondVarSignal_Impl had a parameter like OS_object_token_t *token_ptr and inside it assigned to the parameter variable (e.g. token_ptr = NULL or token_ptr = some_other_address), thereby modifying the pointer parameter itself. That would violate MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8. Note that modifying *token_ptr (the pointed-to object) would be permitted.
